item.title: Wats wrong with this coding
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

[quote=“Galook, post:7, topic:3273”]Or… with fancy in the pantsy java 1.5 (or 5.0) and its auto-boxing and auto-unboxing, you could just do this:

int speed = new Integer(str[0]);

I havent compared their speeds, but since you are only really doing it once per execution of your code, they both work well :)[/quote]
Forgot about that one…never use it, so I dismissed it. Btw, each of these methods take the same amount of time as they each call parseInt(String s, int radix). So there’s no difference…it’s just personal preference.

Read full topic

item.title: Wats wrong with this coding
item.dc:creator: @Galook Galook
item.description:
@Galook wrote:

Or… with fancy in the pantsy java 1.5 (or 5.0) and its auto-boxing and auto-unboxing, you could just do this:

int speed = new Integer(str[0]);

I havent compared their speeds, but since you are only really doing it once per execution of your code, they both work well

Read full topic

item.title: Wats wrong with this coding
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

[quote=“Pwnd, post:5, topic:3273”][quote author=Rictoo link=topic=3820.msg37383#msg37383 date=1148565167]
I’ve never used valueOf and therefore have no knowlege of it
[/quote]
That was very usefull of you.

Couldn’t you just do: int speed = (int) str[0]; ?[/quote]
Nope…how do you cast a String object as a primitive integer?

You need to use Integer.parseInt, Integer.valueOf, or you can analyze each character in the String sequence to build your own integer

Read full topic

item.title: Wats wrong with this coding
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

^^

Also, the int parameter in valueOf is the radix parameter, in case you want to read the integer in anything other than base 10. parseInt also has a second parameter for that as well.

Read full topic

item.title: Wats wrong with this coding
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

int is a primitive type. Instead, use this:

Integer.parseInt(str[0]);

That will return a primitive int value. If you want to use you’re way, valueOf will return a Integer wrapper class type, after which you need to get the primitive int type value (unless you use jdk 1.5+ which has autoboxing and auto-unboxing)

Read full topic

item.title: Wats wrong with this coding
item.dc:creator: @SETO SETO
item.description:
@SETO wrote:

class chap_4_exe5
{
public static void main (String str[])
{
int a = 90;
int b = 50;
int c = 20;

    int speed = int.valueOf (str[0]).intValue ();
    if (speed >= a)
        System.out.println (speed + "->> Exceeding Speed Limit!!");
    else if
        (speed <= c)
        System.out.println (speed + "->> Moving at funeral speed!");
    else
        System.out.println (speed + "->> With Speed Limit!");
}

}

i get error:
---------------- JDK Debug Build ------------------
Compiling H:\chap_4_exe5.java
H:\chap_4_exe5.java:17: class expected
int speed = int.valueOf(int[0]).intValue();
^
1 error
Finished
wats wrong

Read full topic
